title: Brazil legend Rivaldo urges Barcelona not to rush Lionel Messi back after spell on sidelines
text:
Lionel Messi might have played his first 90 minutes of the season for Barcelona in midweek, but the club's former striker Rivaldo says he must not be rushed back into the starting XI.

The Argentine played a starring role as he helped the Catalan outfit fight back to beat Inter Milan in the Champions League on Wednesday, setting up teammate Luis Suarez to net the winner.

The 32-year-old has endured a frustrating campaign with a foot injury restricting him to only two starts - a major factor in the club's slow start which has left them fourth in La Liga.

A troublesome foot injury has kept Lionel Messi on the sidelines for much of this season

Manager Ernesto Valverde knows how vital Messi is to Barca's prospects and it would be a tough call to leave him on the bench, but Rivaldo says the club must take their time in bringing the superstar back into the fold.

'Lionel Messi is still recovering from injury and finding his rhythm,' Rivaldo said, speaking in his role as an ambassador for bookmakers Betfair on Friday.

'But I was happy to see him playing for 90 minutes and sacrificing himself for the team, even if it was obvious that he's not 100% fit.'

'Messi's importance in this win against Inter only reinforces my view that he has to be more protected in this phase of his career.

World Cup winner Rivaldo says Messi must be 'protected' in order to prolong his career

Messi helps Barcelona start an attacking move in the Champions League tie with Inter Milan

'He must be allowed to fully recover so that he can stop feeling any pain and lose any fear of fighting for each ball. He must be allowed to recover his joy on the pitch, as he is very important for Barcelona, especially when on his best form.'

Barcelona face sixth-placed Sevilla on Sunday, with both teams level on 13 points from seven games and, while Messi is more than likely to feature in only his third La Liga game of the season, Rivaldo urges caution.

'Of course Messi wants to play. But it could be time to reflect with the medical staff and check if playing too much time after coming back from an injury could be risky for his recovery,' he said.

'It's an important match against Sevilla but there is a lot of the league season to play yet, so perhaps protecting the player could reap rewards later, as it would allow Messi to have some more days to recover from his midweek efforts.'
description: The 32-year-old has endured a frustrating campaign with a foot injury restricting him to only two starts -- a major factor in the club's slow start which has left them fourth in La Liga.
